selectedPark.description: Grand Canyon National Park, in Northern Arizona, encompasses 278 miles (447 km) of the Colorado River and adjacent uplands. Located on ancestral homeland of 11 Associated Tribes, Grand Canyon is one of the most spectacular examples of erosion anywhere in the world—unmatched in the incomparable vistas it offers visitors from the rim. South Rim is open. North Rim closed for winter. Daily updates >

entranceFees.description: Admits one single, private, non-commercial vehicle and all its passengers. Organized groups are not eligible for the vehicle permit.
entranceFees.title: Grand Canyon National Park Vehicle Permit

entranceFees.description: Admits one single, private, non-commercial motorcycle and its passenger(s).
entranceFees.title: Grand Canyon National Park Motorcycle Permit

entranceFees.description: Admits one individual when entering by foot, bicycle, park shuttle bus, Grand Canyon Railway and private rafting trip. Individuals 15 years old and younger are admitted free of charge.
entranceFees.title: Grand Canyon National Park Individual Permit

entrancePasses.description: Valid for twelve months from the date of purchase, for unlimited visits to Grand Canyon National Park. It admits the purchaser and any accompanying persons in a single, private, non-commercial vehicle, or the purchaser and accompanying immediate family (spouse, children, parents) when entry is by other means (train, shuttle, bicycle, and foot).
entrancePasses.title: Grand Canyon National Park Annual Pass

selectedPark.directionsInfo: South Rim: Open all year, is located 60 miles north of Williams, Arizona (via route 64 from Interstate 40) and 80 miles northwest of Flagstaff (via route 180). Grand Canyon lies entirely within the state of Arizona. North Rim: Closed for the Winter between December 1 and May 15. The North Rim is located 30 miles south of Jacob Lake on Highway 67; the actual rim of the canyon is an additional 14 miles south. Jacob Lake, AZ is located in northern Arizona on Highway 89A, not far from the Utah border.

operatingHours.description: Both Desert View (East Entrance) and South Entrance are Open 24 hours/day and 7 Days/week. Credit cards, Recreation.gov, Your Pass Now, and America the Beautiful passes are accepted for entry. Cash is not accepted at this time. The South Entrance Station, near Tusayan, Arizona, receives the most traffic, an experiences long lines and up to 2 hour wait times between 9:30 am and 4 pm. The East Entrance at Desert View (accessed via US 89 to Cameron, AZ, then west on SR 64, usually has shorter wait times.
operatingHours.name: South Rim - South Entrance

operatingHours.description: The North Rim has a short season. Facilities and lodging are usually open May 15 through October 15, each year. Lodging and Camping Reservations are strongly recommended. The North Rim is over 8000 feet/2438 m. in elevation. Individuals with respiratory or heart problems may experience difficulties. Walking at this elevation can be strenuous. The North Rim is closed to all vehicles between December 1st and May 15th, and no visitor services are available.
operatingHours.name: North Rim

operatingHours.description: The East Entrance to the park at Desert View is open 24 hours/day, 7 days/week. Visitors traveling through the Navajo Nation on US 89, turn west at Cameron, Arizona onto State Route 64, then drive 25 miles (40 km) to the park's East Entrance. A stop at Desert View provides spectacular first views of Grand Canyon and Colorado River. Most Desert View services are open for visitors. Desert View Campground is open for the 2022 season between April 15 and October 16. 2022. Reservations are required.
operatingHours.name: South Rim - Desert View (East Entrance)

images.title: Grand Canyon Mather Point Sunset on the South Rim
images.altText: The canyon glows orange as people visit Mather Point, a rock outcropping that juts into Grand Canyon
images.caption: People come from all over the world to view Grand Canyon's sunset

images.title: Grand Canyon National Park: View from Cape Royal on the North Rim
images.altText: The Cape Royal viewpoint curves into the distance and closer rock formations jut into the canyon.
images.caption: A popular outdoor site for weddings and receptions, Cape Royal Amphitheater is located 23 miles (37 km) from the North Rim developed area.

images.title: Grand Canyon National Park: Desert View Watchtower (South Rim)
images.altText: The Desert View Watchtower looms 70 feet into the air over a vast and dramatic view of the canyon.
images.caption: The Watchtower is located at Desert View, the eastern-most developed area on the South Rim of Grand Canyon National Park.

images.title: Looking down the Colorado River from Nankoweap at river mile 53
images.altText: Tall canyon walls frame the wide Colorado river weaving back and forth.
images.caption: A view down the Colorado river from Nankoweap in Marble canyon.

images.title: Yavapai Point Sunset - Sept. 2021
images.altText: Several dozen people at a scenic overlook with the sun setting on the horizon above a vast canyon la
images.caption: Experiencing sunset from Yavapai Point on the South Rim.

selectedPark.weatherInfo: This weather varies with cold winters and mild pleasant summers, moderate humidity, and considerable diurnal temperature changes at the higher elevations, with hot and drier summers at the bottom of the Grand Canyon along with cool damp winters. Summer thunderstorms and winter snowfall adds to the weather variety in this region.
selectedPark.name: Grand Canyon

selectedEatery.description: You begin to see signs for it about 1,000 miles before you arrive in South Dakota. They promise free ice water. Five-cent coffee. A goddamned Tyrannosaurus rex! There are many, many, many finer restaurants in South Dakota, but none are as famous, for good or ill, as the one in Wall Drug. It's impossible to avoid the Badlands-bordering, 76,000sqft wonder of tourist-trapping randomness, so just go in. Hit the cafe and score a hot beef sandwich and a maple donut. It won't hold a candle to the many, many better food options in the state. But you will emerge with a 'Where the Heck is Wall Drug' sticker. You will have chased that sandwich with a T. rex viewing. And you'll be happy you stopped every time you see a roadside Wall Drug sign every five minutes for the next 300 miles

selectedBizarrerie.name: UFO Crashed Here
selectedBizarrerie.description: Supposedly a UFO crash landed on this site in 1948. Now all that remains is a plaque with the gory details of the crash and some rocks gathered into the shape of an alien’s face.

selectedPark.fullName: Oxon Cove Park & Oxon Hill Farm
selectedPark.description: The diverse history of Maryland and our national heritage can be experienced at Oxon Cove Park. Through hands-on programs and other activities, you can experience farm life and how its changed over time. Explore how the park evolved from a plantation home during the War of 1812, to a hospital farm, to the park you can visit today.

entranceFees.description: Oxon Cove Park & Oxon Hill Farm does not have an admission fee. All programs are free and open to the public unless otherwise indicated.
entranceFees.title: Fee Free Park

selectedPark.directionsInfo: While our mailing address is on Oxon Hill Road, the parking lot entrance to the park is on Bald Eagle Road. Bald Eagle Road can be accessed from the Capital Beltway (I-495/I-95), as well as Indian Head Highway (MD-210) and Oxon Hill Road (MD-414). For detailed directions, please visit our website at http://www.nps.gov/oxhi/planyourvisit/directions.htm

operatingHours.description:
The park opens at 8:00am, 7 days a week, except January 1, Thanksgiving Day, and December 25.  
The gates at the parking lot are locked at 4:30pm every day.
operatingHours.name: Park Grounds

images.title: Cows
images.altText: Two brown cows graze in a field
images.caption: Two Jersey cows graze in their pasture

images.title: Farm Sunrise
images.altText: Sunrise at the Farm
images.caption: Sunrise at the Farm

images.title: Farrier
images.altText: Farrier repairs horse hooves
images.caption: Our farrier regularly maintains the hooves of the horses at Oxon Hill Farm.

images.title: Pigs
images.altText: Young visitors meet the pigs.
images.caption: Young visitors meet the pigs at Oxon Hill Farm.

images.title: Mount Welby
images.altText: A white brick two story building
images.caption: Mount Welby is the oldest structure on the farm, built around 1811

images.title: Oxon Cove Trail
images.altText: A paved walkway along a wooded shoreline
images.caption: The Oxon Cove trail takes hikers and bikers through forest and meadow ecosystems and along Oxon Cove

selectedPark.weatherInfo: Make sure that you wear appropriate shoes and clothing. Closed-toe shoes are recommended, sneakers or comfortable boots are best. Dress for the season, light clothes in summer, layers in spring and fall, and warm coats in winter. Cooler days are often the best days to visit Oxon Hill Farm if you’re interested in seeing farm animals or wildlife out and about. There are still lots of things to see and do on hotter days, just make sure to keep hydrated and take frequent breaks.
selectedPark.name: Oxon Cove Park & Oxon Hill Farm

selectedEatery.description: Staking a claim as Ohio's oldest continually operated business, this joint's got some serious history. Located between Cincinnati and the old National Rd, the hotel and restaurant welcomed everyone from railroad workers to 12 presidents, writers like Mark Twain and Chuck Dickens, and everyone in between. More importantly, the food's good. And yes, lamb is served in the ancient, historic joint.

selectedBizarrerie.name: Ghostbusters Headquarters
selectedBizarrerie.description: The Tribeca firehouse Hook and Ladder Company 8 was used as the Ghostbusters headquarters in the film Ghostbusters and it’s still around and super easy to get to. This New York City attraction is right off of a subway line and full of nods to its film history. According to Roadside America, when actor Harold Ramis died in 2014, fans set up a memorial on the sidewalk outside of the fire house.

selectedPark.description: Not just a great valley, but a shrine to human foresight, the strength of granite, the power of glaciers, the persistence of life, and the tranquility of the High Sierra. First protected in 1864, Yosemite National Park is best known for its waterfalls, but within its nearly 1,200 square miles, you can find deep valleys, grand meadows, ancient giant sequoias, a vast wilderness area, and much more.

entranceFees.description: This fee is valid for seven days.
entranceFees.title: Non-commercial car, pickup truck, RV, or van with 15 or fewer passenger seats

entranceFees.description: This fee is valid for seven days. Cost is per motorcycle (not per person).
entranceFees.title: Motorcycle

entranceFees.description: This fee is valid for seven days. People 15 years and younger are free. Cost is per person.
entranceFees.title: Foot, bicycle, horse, or non-commercial bus or van with more than 15 passenger seats

entranceFees.description: The fee is $25 plus $20 per person.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Tour (sedan up to six seats)
Commercial Tour (van, 7-15 seats, regardless of occupancy)
Commercial Tour (mini bus, 16-25 seats, regardless of occupancy)
Commercial Tour (motor coach, 26 or more seats, regardless of occupancy)

entrancePasses.description: Annual pass providing free entrance to Yosemite for 12 months from the date of purchase.
entrancePasses.title: Yosemite Annual Pass

entrancePasses.description: Annual pass covering entrance and standard amenity fees for national parks and other federal fee areas, valid for 12 months from date of purchase. This replaces the National Parks Pass and Golden Eagle Pass.
entrancePasses.title: America the Beautiful—National Parks and Federal Recreational Lands Annual Pass

entrancePasses.description: Lifetime or annual admission and discount pass for US citizens or permanent residents who are age 62 or older. An annual version of this pass, valid for 12 months, costs $20.
entrancePasses.title: Senior Pass

entrancePasses.description: Lifetime admission and discount pass for US citizens or permanent residents with permanent disabilities.
entrancePasses.title: Access Pass

entrancePasses.description: Annual pass covering entrance and standard amenity fees for all active US military personnel and their dependents, valid for 12 months from date of issuance. (For active duty military personnel and dependents with proper identification (CAC Card or DD Form 1173).)
entrancePasses.title: Annual Pass for US Military

entrancePasses.description: Annual pass covering entrance fees for 4th grade students for 2018–2019 school year.
entrancePasses.title: Annual 4th Grade Pass

selectedPark.directionsInfo: You can drive to Yosemite year-round and enter via Highways 41, 140, and 120 from the west. Tioga Pass Entrance (via Highway 120 from the east) is closed from approximately November through late May or June. Hetch Hetchy is open all year but may close intermittently due to snow. Please note that GPS units do not always provide accurate directions to or within Yosemite.

operatingHours.description: Yosemite National Park is open 24 hours per day, 365 days per year.
operatingHours.name: Yosemite National Park

operatingHours.description: Hetch Hetchy area is only open during the day (except for permitted backpackers). All day visitors must exit Hetch Hetchy by the closure time.
operatingHours.name: Hetch Hetchy

images.title: Upper Yosemite Fall and Merced River in spring
images.altText: Upper Yosemite Fall and Merced River in spring
images.caption: Upper Yosemite Fall and Merced River in spring

images.title: Yosemite Valley from Tunnel View
images.altText: Glaciated valley with vertical cliffs.
images.caption: Tunnel View is perhaps one of the most photographed views in the park.

images.title: Rainbow over Half Dome
images.altText: A rainbow over a mountain in the distance.
images.caption: A hike up to Sentinel Dome rewards people with great views of the landscape around them.

images.title: Cathedral Peak and Lake in Autumn
images.altText: A mountain reflecting in a lake.
images.caption: Cathedral Peak is one of the most recognizable peaks in the Yosemite Wilderness.

images.title: Lower Yosemite Fall
images.altText: A waterfall flowing down a granite cliff.
images.caption: The walk to Lower Yosemite Fall is a popular and easy hike.

images.title: Yosemite Falls on a Winter Morning
images.altText: Two tall waterfalls flowing down snow covered granite walls.
images.caption: Yosemite Falls will sometimes only trickle at the end of summer, but wet winters can rejuvenate the flow.

images.title: Glen Aulin
images.altText: Mountains reflecting in water
images.caption: Glen Auilin is one of five High Sierra Camps, located in the Yosemite high country.

images.title: Giant Sequoia Trees in the Mariposa Grove of Giant Sequoias
images.altText: Cluster of tall trees with cloudy sky.
images.caption: Yosemite National Park's massive giant sequoias (Sequoiadendron giganteum) live in three groves in the park. The most famous of these is the Mariposa Grove, which contains about 500 mature giant sequoias.

images.title: Tenaya Lake at Sunset
images.altText: Mountains surrounding a lake.
images.caption: Tenaya Lake is a favorite place to stop along the Tioga Road in summer.

images.title: Half Dome
images.altText: Granite dome with trace amounts of snow.
images.caption: Half Dome is one of the most recognizable granitic formations in the world.

images.title: El Capitan
images.altText: El Capitan and reflection in Merced River with some low clouds
images.caption: El Capitan rises over 3,000 feet above the floor of Yosemite Valley.

images.title: View of Yosemite Valley in Winter
images.altText: El Capitan on left, Cathedral Rocks on the right, all covered in snow, low clouds and sun
images.caption: A rewarding view of Yosemite Valley in winter as seen from Tunnel View.

selectedPark.weatherInfo: Yosemite National Park covers nearly 1,200 square miles (3,100 square km) in the Sierra Nevada, with elevations ranging from about 2,000 feet (600 m) to 13,000 ft (4,000 m). Yosemite receives 95% of its precipitation between October and May (and over 75% between November and March). Most of Yosemite is blanketed in snow from about November through May. (Yosemite Valley can be rainy or snowy in any given winter storm.)
selectedPark.name: Yosemite

selectedEatery.description: You begin to see signs for it about 1,000 miles before you arrive in South Dakota. They promise free ice water. Five-cent coffee. A goddamned Tyrannosaurus rex! There are many, many, many finer restaurants in South Dakota, but none are as famous, for good or ill, as the one in Wall Drug. It's impossible to avoid the Badlands-bordering, 76,000sqft wonder of tourist-trapping randomness, so just go in. Hit the cafe and score a hot beef sandwich and a maple donut. It won't hold a candle to the many, many better food options in the state. But you will emerge with a 'Where the Heck is Wall Drug' sticker. You will have chased that sandwich with a T. rex viewing. And you'll be happy you stopped every time you see a roadside Wall Drug sign every five minutes for the next 300 miles

selectedBizarrerie.name: Love Butt
selectedBizarrerie.description: This 10-foot-tall, 1,600-pound piece of artwork was originally featured on a comedy show pilot but is now a permanent fixture in Charlottesville, Virginia. Big, pink, and embarrassing, it’s the perfect road trip attraction for using the “I’m just pulling over to use the restroom” excuse.

selectedPark.fullName: Abraham Lincoln Birthplace National Historical Park
selectedPark.description: For over a century people from around the world have come to rural Central Kentucky to honor the humble beginnings of our 16th president, Abraham Lincoln. His early life on Kentucky's frontier shaped his character and prepared him to lead the nation through Civil War. Visit our country's first memorial to Lincoln, built with donations from young and old, and the site of his childhood home.

entranceFees.description: There is no fee associated with visiting either unit of the park.
entranceFees.title: Fee Free Park

selectedPark.directionsInfo: The Birthplace Unit of the park is located approximately 2 miles south of the town of Hodgenville on U.S. Highway 31E South. The Boyhood Home Unit at Knob Creek is located approximately 10 miles northeast of the Birthplace Unit of the park.

operatingHours.description:
Memorial Building:
open 9:00 am - 4:30 pm eastern time.

Birthplace Unit Visitor Center and Grounds: 
open 9:00 am - 5:00 pm eastern time.
operatingHours.name: Birthplace Unit

exceptions.name: Spring Hours - Visitor Center at Knob Creek
Fall Hours - Knob Creek Visitor Center

operatingHours.description:
The Boyhood Home Unit at Knob Creek Grounds:
open daily dawn to dusk.

Knob Creek Tavern Visitor Center:
open on weekends in April, May, September and October and 5 days a week from Memorial Day to Labor day from 10 am to 4pm (Thursday - Monday) closed for the winter.
operatingHours.name: Boyhood Unit

images.title: The Memorial Building with fall colors
images.altText: The Memorial Building surrounded by fall colors
images.caption: Over 200,000 people a year come to walk up the steps of the Memorial Building to visit the site where Abraham Lincoln was born

images.title: The Memorial Building
images.altText: The first memorial erected to honor Abraham Lincoln
images.caption: The Memorial Building constructed on the traditional site of the birth of Abraham Lincoln.

images.title: The Symbolic Birth Cabin of Abraham Lincoln
images.altText: The symbolic birth cabin on the traditional site of the birth of Abraham Lincoln.
images.caption: The symbolic birth cabin of Abraham Lincoln.

images.title: Statue of the Lincoln Family in the Visitor Center
images.altText: Statue of the Lincoln family in the park's Visitor Center
images.caption: Visitors to the park can view the statue of the Lincoln family.

selectedPark.weatherInfo: There are four distinct seasons in Central Kentucky. However, temperature and weather conditions can vary widely within those seasons. Spring and Fall are generally pleasant with frequent rain showers. Summer is usually hot and humid. Winter is moderately cold with mixed precipitation.
selectedPark.name: Abraham Lincoln Birthplace

selectedEatery.description: Alabama's place in the great lexicon of barbecue rests squarely on the shoulders of one man: Big Bob Gibson. While other BBQ regions were dancing with brisket and ribs and pork, in 1925, Gibson started smoking chicken in a hand-dug pit in his backyard and serving folks on a picnic table. (He also served pork, but that's such a side note to the chicken here.) In addition to making chicken the star -- rather than the weird, dry BBQ’d poultry coated in a congealed sauce that's served at every company picnic ever -- Gibson rolled out his now-famous, peppery mayo-cider vinegar-lemon white sauce that’s synonymous with Alabama barbecue.

selectedBizarrerie.name: Big White Shirt
selectedBizarrerie.description: Andalusia, Alabama, is the white dress-shirt capital of America, and this highly photographed enormous white shirt sign is a reminder of that. According to Roadside America, the tie is changed seasonally.
